threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Go /p/ro:
• Please post images that are JPG format and ideally smaller than 1 MB, and/or about 1000 pixels on the longest side.
• Expect to be judged harshly. Learn to deal with it.

Want:
• We come here for photos, so post yours as often as possible, even if "image unrelated" to your text.
• "Flickr/500px/Tumblr/Facebook/Portfolio" threads are for critique and networking.
• Use "Recent Photos" threads if you are shy or only want to post a couple of photos.
• Shared raw files which we can collectively edit for discussion of post-processing techniques, are encouraged.
• Use the Catalog to consolidate similar topics (photographic themes, images or technical gear threads).

Do not want:
• Go to /wsr/ or /r/ for specific Photoshop requests.
• Gear threads are discouraged, but identified as necessary. Many users simply hide these threads.

Want to learn more?
• The /p/ Wiki

>>4104894
raid0 is a terrible idea, either drive broken results in totalndata loss
i would use the remaining M.2 slot for a 2TB drive for storage. sata ssd is also a decent option
i myself have a home server with snapraid that i use for backup and long term storage
PC is 2x2TB M.2 drives for general purpose use and a couple sata ssds and mechanical hdds for eroge/porn/"other stuff" ;)
i do also have some cronjobs running on my server that fetches files from my PC to make backups, directory trees are mirrored so the layout is the same. tar.gz and uncompressed copies both
uncompressed backup folder on the server i have remotely mounted on my PC for easy easy to access
i get around 80MB/s read/write speed on the remote folder, but thats mostly limited by the gigabit ethernet and SFTP

threads.com:
Yes it's another gear thread, sorry guys. But you'll tell it to me like it is with no hype or shilling.

So I'm looking into buying into a full frame mirrorless system. I shoot seriously, but not professionally (I don't depend on it for my main income). I'm looking at used cameras in the 'enthusiast / low end professional' spectrum, so basically SontyA7(R/S)ii/iii, Nikon Z6i/ii, Canon EOS R. I'm hoping to get a used camera, and one or two decent primes for around 2000 USD.

I shoot mainly event photography at 'alternative events', very frequently wth poor or moody lighting, so low light performance and noise quality is important to me. I am a huge raw processing / color calibration geek, so I basically don't care at all about how images look SOOC.

Yes, I know that it's the photographer and not the gear and all that, but also I'm looking at spending quite a bit of money and buying into an ecosystem here so I'd like to consider my options carefully.

So are there any clear winners here, or clear losers to avoid?

How is this phenomenon called in which a similar lens renders a picture in a more tridimentional way?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4104789
I said it has the 3d pop look but it's a little more realistic rather than looking like a bad lightroom edit to shove more contrast where no one wants it. Some zeiss lenses look like absolute fucking ass and people gravitated towards leica for that precise reason. Zeiss and pentax are siblings in rendering, their lenses have a little more distortion and go heavy on contrast and good color reproduction. These lenses have very little flare so things don't wash out and you see strong shadows giving everything dimensionality. However sharpness suffers just a little for this and you can go way too far and add contrast and distortion that shouldn't be there. Tamron and nikon are honorable mentions here and a lot of people contract out to tamron, nikon included because they can make a good lens once in a while and their design philosophy fits in well with pentax and nikon's lineup. Leica and sigma are sisters also, they historically prioritize sharpness and you get these very detailed images that look a little flat and faded, but sigma lenses are just built worse than leicas and while they get medically sharp but the images just don't look as good.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Crushed dreams and lost hope Edition
All video related questions and discussion is intended for this thread. Here we discuss techniques, gear and anything else related to capturing video footage. Please don't pretend to be an expert if you don't know what you're talking about. Kindly leave your ego at the door.
Posting short films/scripts or other work you've done is encouraged.
We tend to use and recommend DSLRs/mirrorless cameras because they provide phenomenal picture quality for their price, have large sensors (ie the same size used in high-end cinema cameras and higher) and have interchangeable lenses.
In contrast, consumer camcorders normally have much smaller sensors and a fixed lens.

>STICKY -https://textbin.net/2u146abxla
>Helpful guide, additional books and more in-depth FAQs - https://web.archive.org/web/20200926115310/https://pastebin.com/kG0gRmTZ

>NO ONE CARES WHAT AN EXPERT YOU THINK YOU ARE. IF YOU’RE ASKING BASIC-AS-SHIT QUESTIONS, YOU CAN’T BE ALL THAT GREAT. SEE ABOVE

Previous thread >>4095075

Quick FAQS
>what’s the best camera available on a “budget”?
The blackmagic pocket cinema camera 4k
>>what’s a good beginner video camera?
Anything that works, shoots at least 1080p and preferably has interchangeable lenses. Any recommendation beyond that will cause arguments so read the fucking sticky if that isn't satisfactory.
>Can I use a zoom lens for video?
Yes
>Do I need cine lenses?
No
>Do I need 4k?
No. It will make your footage look sharper if it’s in focus, and it gives you breathing room in post. But 1080p is still absolutely fine
>Can someone tell me if my video is any good?
Yes, but be prepared to receive harsh criticism. If you're going to waste 5 minutes of our time with a shitty out-of-focus montage of nothing then we'll tell you that it's crap

last_replies.com:
>>4089524
You're getting confused by a common legal trick. Companies add some kind of handshake or encryption to a communication protocol and then they copyright the key or the handshake as code. When you manage to make the protocol work they can sue you for copyright infringement and claim you copied their code.

Of course Viltrox didn't, you can't copy Canon's code. It's not public, they're not posting it on GitHub. What you can do is disassemble the firmware to get the handshakes or the encryption keys, which Canon claims is code. This is the same trick that Apple uses so that for example you can't make the Apple Watch work on Android or so that no headphones except the Airpods can have their audio feature. If someone figures out how to make it work Apple can sue them for copying the code that's necessary to make to make it work. Except it's not really code anyone wrote it's more like a key you're forced to duplicate and that US law considers to be code.

threads.com: Hey /p/ bros, I've been out of the camera game for a couple of years (last camera owned was a D3400 with a kit lens and a 70-300) and I am looking to upgrade to a new camera for around (preferably at or under) $2000 CAD. This price would just include the body and I would budget extra for lenses. I've been looking at the Z5, but I hear it has some issues with image quality (lack of BSI) and low-light performance, and I want to shoot hi-quality low light photos and landscape photos. There is also a good deal for an A7 II with a kit lens at $1400 but I'm not sure whether it's worth buying a near decade-old camera. Lastly (if you couldn't tell) I want to shoot full frame, but if you guys recommend any good APS-C cameras (I was looking at the A6400) then I would consider that too.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4104499
That's a great price for a very usable camera.

Unless you need exceptionally good tracking autofocus that's a no brainer at that price.

And I wouldn't worry too much about super fast lenses, my most used lens is a 35mm f2.8, even though I also have an f1.4 35mm.

What do you want to shoot?

If you buy used lenses, they'll retain a lot of their value in resale, so if that's a you can afford for now, ho for them, if you want better resolution\bokeh\af in the future you can sell the old one and it was effectively almost free for you to use.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4104548
Get the cheap viltrox then, that was the only circumstance I'd suggest it for. A good tripod is twice as important though!

An autofocus Samyang 24mm f1.8 I'd say is a much more useful lens though, but as I said, 2nd hand is practically free, so get the viltrox to play with if you want 20mm.

Also remember the wider you go, the longer exposures you can do before the earth's rotation becomes an issue. So something like the ttartisan 11mm f2.8 may also be something that interests you, and is very affordable too.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
• Theme: Reflections
• Deadline: From 6 November to 27 November

Theme:
• The photo has to feature a reflection
• The reflection does not have to be very clear, but it has to clearly be a reflection

Rules:
• Photo must be taken during the timeline. Images taken before this thread was started won't count.
• Post images with exif, if possible. If you can't, just state that they were taken during the timeline.
• Three entries per photographer max.
• A day after the competition ends, all valid images will be posted for voting.

Optional:
• You're encouraged to post your images that fit the theme even if they're out of competition.
• You may name your images if you wish.

Other:
• Feedback on the themes or the organization of the competition is greatly appreciated

These telescoping tripods aren't usable for heavy cameras. I have a prinz one with steel legs and it's clearly unstable and leaning/bending with a light film SLR and anything heavier than a short prime. With the legs collapsed, they make good tabletop mounts for small spotting scopes, and are usable for very light and well balanced camera setups but nothing bigger. I keep mine in my range bag and use it to hold up phones for phonetography if those are the cameras that are available.

What is the connection between AI (or rather neural networks) being able to generate photorealistic images and your own photography? If I sit in the woods for a couple hours waiting to get a nice shot of a bird or other animal, go home empty handed multiple times, all that makes the final picture all the more rewarding. I can print it, hang it on my wall and be reminded that I managed to get that picture. Same with most other things most amateur shoot. Portrait, nude art, street, landscape etc. It's about you getting the shot you want.

Unless you make your income from stock photography I do not think professionals have to worry too much either. No one is gonna "AI" their wedding, or the shots of the new product. Wildlife and landscape is also strongly bound to reality.

All video related questions and discussion is intended for this thread. Here we discuss techniques, gear and anything else related to capturing video footage. Please don't pretend to be an expert if you don't know what you're talking about. Kindly leave your ego at the door.
Posting short films/scripts or other work you've done is encouraged.
We tend to use and recommend DSLRs/mirrorless cameras because they provide phenomenal picture quality for their price, have large sensors (ie the same size used in high-end cinema cameras and higher) and have interchangeable lenses.
In contrast, consumer camcorders normally have much smaller sensors and a fixed lens.

>STICKY -https://textbin.net/2u146abxla
>Helpful guide, additional books and more in-depth FAQs - https://web.archive.org/web/20200926115310/https://pastebin.com/kG0gRmTZ

>NO ONE CARES WHAT AN EXPERT YOU THINK YOU ARE. IF YOU’RE ASKING BASIC-AS-SHIT QUESTIONS, YOU CAN’T BE ALL THAT GREAT. SEE ABOVE

Previous thread >>4085831

Quick FAQS
>what’s the best camera available on a “budget”?
The blackmagic pocket cinema camera 4k
>>what’s a good beginner video camera?
Anything that works, shoots at least 1080p and preferably has interchangeable lenses. Any recommendation beyond that will cause arguments so read the fucking sticky if that isn't satisfactory.
>Can I use a zoom lens for video?
Yes
>Do I need cine lenses?
No
>Do I need 4k?
No. It will make your footage look sharper if it’s in focus, and it gives you breathing room in post. But 1080p is still absolutely fine
>Can someone tell me if my video is any good?
Yes, but be prepared to receive harsh criticism. If you're going to waste 5 minutes of our time with a shitty out-of-focus montage of nothing then we'll tell you that it's crap

Of course. Cameras are just tools. Each one is different. Some more than others.

I started with Yashica TLRs. They are relatively inexpensive and have good lenses. I still use them as a backup because they are light and small. I do a lot of backpacking and enjoy the weight aspect.

I then started using a Kiev 60. The lenses are cheap and decent. The cameras are finicky and very heavy. Depending on the camera you might have to mess with it to get it running. Mine runs great now although it can be frustrating to deal with the dim focusing screen. The downside is that the lenses are limited and I really like Zeiss lenses. I am using a Pentacon 50mm and it is my favorite in the P6 lineup.

I saved up and bought a Hassy 500cm body and a Distagon 50mm. Have not received the lens yet. They are insanely expensive and I paid out the ass for an extra clean one. Nice bright screen, the sharpest lenses and lots of options. I have used one before and I instantly fell in love with it. I bought it because I like nice things and enjoying the process is 50% of the fun for me.

threads.com:
Talk about something you get autistic over in photography.
I'll start.

I've followed this advice since the start of time, if I am to shoot handheld and there's not enough light, and my camera has let's say a 50mm lens on. My lowest acceptable shutter speed should be 1/50s. In practice if I hold very very steady I can maybe go to 1/30s and still get an acceptable image.
Now. If on crop sensors, because of the crop factor, a 33mm lens is equivalent to a 50mm while letting me shoot with a 1/30s all the while getting a good image would mean technically that it is better at low light photography, excluding noise and desired photo characteristics.
But... Larger sensors have less noise, which sort of balances the need for a theoretically higher acceptable shutter speed. But to what extent?
Also, if a camera has sensor stabilization, how far can I push my acceptable shutter speed below the normal acceptable speed? 1 stop? 2 stops?
Looking at the tiny amount of data regarding this online (maybe because most photographers are not this autistic), I'm starting to think that a newer, less noisy, image stabilized APS-C camera might reign supreme in terms of low light handheld shooting.

What are your thoughts on using a speed booster on a crop camera body?

These things supposedly reduce the crop factor and gain about a stop of light. For instance a Canon "nifty fifty" would go from a 50x1.6=80mm f/1.8 on a crop sensor to a 50x1.6x0.71=57mm f/1.2.

These seem to be available for several different brands and lens mounts, at varying price points.

>>4103636
Most still photographers use mirrorless bro.

Mirrorless is just the future of tech even if you like DSLRs. Because even if you like DSLRs and have no use for fancy AF algorithms, higher burst rates, and exposure previews, it's less moving parts and a less than half the size, and since the majority of sales care about at least one half of that benefit list more than they care about OVFs being fun an MILC will always get an improved sensor first.

But anyways speed boosters are a waste of money and negate most of the advantages of using a smaller sensor for a very slight decrease in ISO noise.

threads.name: Zach
threads.com:
Okay if light is traveling all over the place and it is clear and colored, why doesn't it look as trippy as pic related?

[EXIF data available. Click here to show/hide.]
Camera-Specific Properties:
Image-Specific Properties:
Image OrientationUnknown

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4103113
>>4103115
anon is correct. the lens in your eye ball focuses light to the retina (although it struggles with higher wavelengths so blue and violet are never actually in focus but it's close enough for your brain to cope and compensate).

when light is traveling through air it's generally all wavelengths which we are not particularly sensitive to in terms of colour, only as luminance. when it strikes an object of a certain colour or pigment it means that object absorbs all the wavelengths that aren't the colour but reflects wavelenghts that are that colour. your pupil is narrow enough that scattered reflections don't get to your retina, only the reflections that are arriving more directly to the pupil, further focused by the lens in your eye. this is why peripheral vision is always out of focus even if you try to draw your attention to it, and also why technically your eye is only ever focused on a single pinpoint but your visual system is quite adept at making you feel as though you are grasping the whole scene in front of you, largely through central nervous system processing and constant micro glances to scan the scene in front of you.

fun fax: the very center of our vision has very slow response to movement and sees absolutely nothing but color (i.e. no contrast at all) but it is the only part of our vision that is actually in focus. the periphery of our vision is extremely sensitive to movement and is biased toward contrast and sees very little color. in reality our vision is incredibly weak and dull in relationship to many of our animal cousins.

during scotopic vision (when your eyes are adjusted to seeing in low light) you are completely blind to whatever you look directly at. if you want to have a look at something, you have to glance away slightly and it'll appear in your peripheral vision, and never in focus. the extreme sensitivity to movement that we experience in our peripheral vision is what kept us from getting ate by the dinosaurs.

try making a pinhole camera someday. your pupils are small enough so that only light arriving at narrrow angles reaches the focal point of the retina. that alone keeps objects in focus, scattered random light does not reach your retinas, only the light coming from objects you're looking at reaches the retina.

the lens in your eye further focuses the light to make it sharper and also to allow your eyes to adapt to different depths of field

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: I bought a Canon R10 - Did I make a mistake?
threads.com:
So 5-6 years ago I purchased a Canon 6D with a "nifty fifty" as well as a 35mm Sigma Art f/1.4 lens. It cost me about $2000, which was a lot of money for me at the time (especially since I'm only a hobby photographer).

Anyway, I wanted to upgrade to a mirrorless camera due to its better autofocusing system etc, so after a lot of reading (I was mostly researching full frame cameras), I ended up ordering an APS-C camera (the Canon R10).

My thinking was, due to the 1.6x crop factor, my 50mm would become an 80mm lens and my 35mm Sigma would become 56mm. And I wanted a lens in this region for portrait photography.

But now I hear that just attaching one of these full frame lenses via an EF to RF mount, could actually make the IQ worse.

Did I make a mistake buying a cropped sensor camera? Especially since I mostly do portrait photography nowadays? Should I have just sold everything I had and started fresh with a full-frame Sony or Nikon?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101136
Sensor size isn’t a meme if you compare over larger distances, like MFT to FF. If you are anything but a fair weather person the boost in dynamic range and better noise to signal ratio is noticeable then. APSC to FF and FF to MF? Bet money and tell me which prints came from which camera. Many have failed at a rate equal to a coin flip. APSC to MF? You could probably tell. When you push them to the extremes of shitty light and high dynamic range in one exposure it gets obvious even APSC to FF but night photographers are a minority and many of them appreciate a compressed lofi look.

If it's still photography, you can either use live view and zoom focus, or you can use the rangefinder with the AI FOCUS acquisition and then recompose. Otherwise you should be able to do just fine with AI FOCUS and fast shutter speed.

I don't have this issue why using a kiss body, so you shouldn't really have issues with a 6D.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Use an old film lens (the rendering style, color cast, and softness are part of the look)
Use a glimmerglass filter (softens highlights... and detail)
Totally kill color noise at the cost of sharpness, leave luminance noise, maybe even increase it.
Shoot in soft natural lighting or git gud. Artificial light, especially flash, was difficult for most people to use for the longest time, so most film shots are either in very good light or ambient light.
Use a fixed white balance. Use a fixed ISO instead of coping and using it and EV values to fix exposures. This is a stylistic choice but the result is film-y thematic consistency shot to shot.

editing is arguably the most important aspect of photography. no matter how interesting your subject, composition, and the overall context of your work is, it must have striking contrast, colors, and other things. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: >>4099188

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4099499
I mean if you want to be a few inches away from your model and still capture a large portion of them then you're gonna have to go somewhat wide. Unless you mean minimum focus distance, in which case on the 16-55 for example is 30cm, on primes like the 18/1.4 and 23/1.4 about 20cm, the 30/2.8 macro can do 10cm. Remember those figures are from the sensor plane, so the 30/2.8 for example has a minimum working distance of about 1.2cm (from the surface of the lens).

The easiest way really is just taking whatever you shoot on FF and dividing that by 1.52. 50mm FF=33mm Fuji, 35mm FF=23mm Fuji, 24mm FF=16mm Fuji. You'll get the same field of view that way. Like >>4099416 and >>4099235 said, you won't run into problems unless you go really really wide, where you'll still find lenses (the 8-16/2.8 for example) but they're basically as expensive as their FF counterparts.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: How does one improve the look of eyelids in portraits? Not asking for postprocessing tips, I want to get it right on camera.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Shoot with the sun shining at an oblique angle into the eyelid for darker eyes, for lighter eyes you can also get away with diffuse light like on an overcast day. Stop down the lens to f/4-5.6, and make sure that your camera is focusing on the eyelid, not into the eyelashes or into reflections in the eye. Shoot at a higher shutter speed than usual. Try to minimize reflections. As for contrast, color and sharpening, that depends on your camera and workflow.
